export const riverDescriptions={'Mula':'Mula River (~58 km) rises in the Sahyadri hills and flows through Pimpri‑Chinchwad, Aundh, Baner, Wakad and Hinjewadi. Historically it supported rich aquatic habitats; today it is stressed by municipal sewage, pharmaceutical and industrial discharges, heavy metals and other chemical pollution.','Mutha':'Mutha River (~65 km) originates at Khadakvasla Dam and shows progressive water‑quality degradation downstream through Warje, Deccan Gymkhana, Shivajinagar and Camp. It serves a population of ~2 million and is affected by sewage, industrial effluent and runoff; concrete channelization has reduced natural self‑purification.','Mula-Mutha':'Confluence at Sangam Bridge is a hydrologically important mixing zone where complex biochemical processes can form toxic compounds. Monsoon flooding can dilute and mobilize pollutants while dry seasons concentrate contaminants — increasing risks to groundwater and highlighting the need for focused monitoring.'};

sourcesContent:

export const getRiverColor = (river) => {
  switch(river) {
    case 'Mula': return '#2196F3';
    case 'Mutha': return '#1976D2';
    case 'Mula-Mutha': return '#FF9800';
    default: return '#9E9E9E';
  }
};

// Brief descriptions for UI (short; suitable for home/tooltip snippets)
export const riverDescriptions = {
  'Mula': 'Mula River (~58 km) rises in the Sahyadri hills and flows through Pimpri‑Chinchwad, Aundh, Baner, Wakad and Hinjewadi. Historically it supported rich aquatic habitats; today it is stressed by municipal sewage, pharmaceutical and industrial discharges, heavy metals and other chemical pollution.',
  'Mutha': 'Mutha River (~65 km) originates at Khadakvasla Dam and shows progressive water‑quality degradation downstream through Warje, Deccan Gymkhana, Shivajinagar and Camp. It serves a population of ~2 million and is affected by sewage, industrial effluent and runoff; concrete channelization has reduced natural self‑purification.',
  'Mula-Mutha': 'Confluence at Sangam Bridge is a hydrologically important mixing zone where complex biochemical processes can form toxic compounds. Monsoon flooding can dilute and mobilize pollutants while dry seasons concentrate contaminants — increasing risks to groundwater and highlighting the need for focused monitoring.'
};
